physdesc.extent: in 33 record cartons, 1 manuscript box, and 1 oversize box.

did.abstract: This collection contains the papers of Murray Zuckoff and Aviva Cantor Zuckoff. Documents in this collection predominantly relate to Murray Zuckoff's career as a journalsist and his work as a political activist. These materials contain documents related to his work with the Socialist Workers' Party, the Jewish Liberation Project, and his work as editor of the Jewish Telegraphic Agency. Some materials relating to Aviva Cantor Zucker are also represented in these papers, although they may not be a numerous. These papers also contain records of the Jewish Liberation Project, of which Murray Zuckoff and Aviva Cantor were founding members, which consist of documents related to their work and day-to-day operations within the organizaiton.
did.langmaterial: Materials are in English and Hebrew

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Donated by Aviva Cantor Zuckoff in 2005; additional materials were donated by Zuckoff in 2010 and 2016. The accession numbers associated with these gifts are 2008.032, 2008.033, 2010.063, 2010.064, and 2016.015.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Materials in this collection have not been arranged.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Murray Zuckoff was the editor-in-chief of the Jewish Telegraphic Agency (JTA) from 1969 to 1987. In his columns, he wrote on a wide range of issues, including Israel, poverty, black-Jewish relations and the about way Jewish issues were covered in the general media. Zuckoff was born on New York City's Lower East Side and was a reporter at Paterson, N.J's The Morning Call before joining to JTA. He later served as an editor of Midstream magazine. He was also a founding member of the Jewish Liberation Project and was a member of Socialist Workers' Party. He died in New York of lung cancer in 2004.

Aviva Cantor Zuckoff was a journalist, activist, and editor. Born in the Bronx in 1940, Cantor served as an editor for many Jewish periodicals including Israel Horizons, Jewish Liberation Journal, Hadassah Magazine, and Lilith, which she helped found in 1976. An advocate for Jewish feminism, Zionism, socialism, animal rights and environmentalism, Cantor published five alternative haggadahs aimed at creating more inclusive Jewish ceremonies, including her most well known, the Egalitarian Haggadah.
Murray Zuckoff and Aviva Cantor Zuckoff were both founding members of the Jewish Liberation Project, a 1960s-era radical group that some say presaged the Jewish counterculture of the 1970s.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The collection name was changed in 2016 to the Muray Zuckoff and Aviva Cantor Zuckoff Papers, when Aviva Cantor Zuckoff was identified as an additional creator of materials in the collection. 33 boxes, which are part of the original donation and make up the bulk of the collection, have not been aranged and have little description. Four boxes of these boxes were separated from the original donation and established as the Jewish Liberation Project Files (TAM 369). These materials were reincorporated into the Murray and Aviva Cantor Zuckoff Papers (TAM 325) in 2016.
An additional two boxes were added to the collection following a 2016 donation and described in the file list as 2016 Accretion.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This collection contains the personal and professional papers of Murray Zuckoff and his wife Aviva Cantor Zuckoff. There is little description for materials in the first 33 boxes of the collection, but these materials primarily relate to Murray Zuckoff's career as a journalsist and his work as a political activist. These materials contain documents related to his work with the Socialist Workers' Party, the Jewish Liberation Project, and as editor of the Jewish Telegraphic Agency. Some materials relating to Aviva Cantor Zucker are also represented in these papers, although they may not be a numerous.

An additional donation of two boxes of Murray Zuckoff and Aviva Cantor Zuckoff's papers were added to the collection in 2016. These materials consist of ephemera and newspaper clippings compliled by Murray Zuckoff and Aviva Cantor Zuckoff, which primarily relate to the Jewish liberation movement and socialist Zionism between the 1970s and 2010. These materials consist of pamplets, magazines, newsletters, flyers, bulletins, and mailings from Jewish organization and publications. Many of the clippings in this donation consist of articles written by Murray Zuckoff on topics related to Jewish activism and the state of Israel. A number of these documents relate the Jewish Liberation Project.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright (and related rights to publicity and privacy) to materials in this collection created by Murry Zuckoff and Aviva Cantor Zuckoff was not transferred to New York University. Permission to use materials must be secured from the copyright holder.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Socialist Workers Party writing, ephemera, caucus and convention notes, correspondence, internal bulletins, (Zuckoff ran as a state senator in this party), Militant Labor Forum materials, Young Socialist Forum materials, International Socialist Review and Fourth International writings. Some speeches and articles written by Zuckoff. Some clippings. Content is very fragile.
